segment.source: Add and Remove Language Packs Offline Using DISM
segment.target: Add and Remove Language Packs Offline Using DISM

segment.source: Add and Remove Language Packs Offline Using DISM
segment.target: Add and Remove Language Packs Offline Using DISM

segment.source: Add and Remove Language Packs Offline Using DISM
segment.target: Add and Remove Language Packs Offline Using DISM

segment.source: All installations of Windows® contain at least one language pack and the language-neutral binaries that make up the core operating system.
segment.target: All installations of Windows® contain at least one language pack and the language-neutral binaries that make up the core operating system.

segment.source: This topic includes information about how to use Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM.exe) to add or remove additional language packs, and to configure international settings.
segment.target: This topic includes information about how to use Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM.exe) to add or remove additional language packs, and to configure international settings.

segment.source: You can use the same procedures to add or remove Language Interface Packs (LIPs).
segment.target: You can use the same procedures to add or remove Language Interface Packs (LIPs).

segment.source: For more information about the difference between a language pack and a LIP, see Add Language Packs to Windows.
segment.target: For more information about the difference between a language pack and a LIP, see Add Language Packs to Windows.

segment.source: The Windows image must be a recently installed and captured image, or the default retail image.
segment.target: The Windows image must be a recently installed and captured image, or the default retail image.

segment.source: This ensures that the Windows image does not have any pending package actions.
segment.target: This ensures that the Windows image does not have any pending package actions.

segment.source: The Windows images can be in any language.
segment.target: The Windows images can be in any language.

segment.source: For example, you can start with an English (en-US) image and add support for Japanese (ja-JP) and Korean (ko-KR).
segment.target: For example, you can start with an English (en-US) image and add support for Japanese (ja-JP) and Korean (ko-KR).

segment.source: In addition, you can add LIPs to a Windows image that contains the supported parent language.
segment.target: In addition, you can add LIPs to a Windows image that contains the supported parent language.

segment.source: For more information about the supported language packs and LIPs, see Language Packs (lp.cab) and Windows Deployment.
segment.target: For more information about the supported language packs and LIPs, see Language Packs (lp.cab) and Windows Deployment.

segment.source: This topic includes the following procedures.
segment.target: This topic includes the following procedures.

segment.source: Add a Language Pack to a Windows Image describes how to add a new language pack to an offline Windows image.
segment.target: Add a Language Pack to a Windows Image describes how to add a new language pack to an offline Windows image.

segment.source: Remove a Language Pack from a Windows Image describes how to use DISM to remove a language pack from an offline Windows image.
segment.target: Remove a Language Pack from a Windows Image describes how to use DISM to remove a language pack from an offline Windows image.

segment.source: You must remove any language packs that you do not intend to use before you add new language packs to a Windows image.
segment.target: You must remove any language packs that you do not intend to use before you add new language packs to a Windows image.

segment.source: Configure International Settings describes how to use DISM to change the default display language and configure other international settings in a Windows image.
segment.target: Configure International Settings describes how to use DISM to change the default display language and configure other international settings in a Windows image.

segment.source: For information about how to add a language pack to a Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) image, see Add a Language Pack to a Windows PE Image.
segment.target: For information about how to add a language pack to a Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) image, see Add a Language Pack to a Windows PE Image.

segment.source: Add a Language Pack to a Windows Image
segment.target: Add a Language Pack to a Windows Image

segment.source: Language packs are available as .cab files and are named Lp.cab.
segment.target: Language packs are available as .cab files and are named Lp.cab.

segment.source: Packages provided as .cab files can be added to an offline Windows image using the DISM command-line tool.
segment.target: Packages provided as .cab files can be added to an offline Windows image using the DISM command-line tool.

segment.source: You can use the same procedure to add a language pack or a Language Interface Pack (LIP).
segment.target: You can use the same procedure to add a language pack or a Language Interface Pack (LIP).

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: LIPs are released as .mlc files.
segment.target: LIPs are released as .mlc files.

segment.source: When you add a LIP to an offline Windows image using the DISM command-line tool, you must rename the LIP file from LIP.mlc to LIP.cab.
segment.target: When you add a LIP to an offline Windows image using the DISM command-line tool, you must rename the LIP file from LIP.mlc to LIP.cab.

segment.source: LIPs can be installed only on a Windows image that has the supported parent languages installed.
segment.target: LIPs can be installed only on a Windows image that has the supported parent languages installed.

segment.source: For example, the Basque (Basque) LIP can be installed only on a Windows image that has the Spanish (Spain) or French (France) parent language pack installed.
segment.target: For example, the Basque (Basque) LIP can be installed only on a Windows image that has the Spanish (Spain) or French (France) parent language pack installed.

segment.source: Before you install a LIP to an offline Windows image, verify that the supported parent languages are installed.
segment.target: Before you install a LIP to an offline Windows image, verify that the supported parent languages are installed.

segment.source: For more information about the supported language packs and LIPs, see Language Packs (lp.cab) and Windows Deployment.
segment.target: For more information about the supported language packs and LIPs, see Language Packs (lp.cab) and Windows Deployment.

segment.source: You can also add language packs and LIPs to an answer file and then apply the answer file to an offline Windows image.
segment.target: You can also add language packs and LIPs to an answer file and then apply the answer file to an offline Windows image.

segment.source: When you do this, you can install the LIP and the parent language in the same operation.
segment.target: When you do this, you can install the LIP and the parent language in the same operation.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Do not install a language pack after an update.
segment.target: Do not install a language pack after an update.

segment.source: If you install an update (hotfix, general distribution release GDR, or service pack SP) that contains language-dependent resources before you install a language pack, the language-specific changes that are contained in the update are not applied and you will have to reinstall the update.
segment.target: If you install an update (hotfix, general distribution release GDR, or service pack SP) that contains language-dependent resources before you install a language pack, the language-specific changes that are contained in the update are not applied and you will have to reinstall the update.

segment.source: Always install language packs before you install updates.
segment.target: Always install language packs before you install updates.

segment.source: To add a language pack using DISM
segment.target: To add a language pack using DISM

segment.source: Before you add new language packs to a Windows image, you must remove any language packs from the Windows image that you do not intend to use.
segment.target: Before you add new language packs to a Windows image, you must remove any language packs from the Windows image that you do not intend to use.

segment.source: For more information, see Remove a Language Pack from a Windows Image.
segment.target: For more information, see Remove a Language Pack from a Windows Image.

segment.source: Click Start, and type deployment.
segment.target: Click Start, and type deployment.

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: If your image is already mounted from the previous procedure, you can type the following command to list the images that are currently mounted and information about the mounted image such as mount location and mounted image index.
segment.target: If your image is already mounted from the previous procedure, you can type the following command to list the images that are currently mounted and information about the mounted image such as mount location and mounted image index.

segment.source: If your image is not mounted, type the following command to retrieve the name or index number for the image that you want to modify.
segment.target: If your image is not mounted, type the following command to retrieve the name or index number for the image that you want to modify.

segment.source: An index or name value is required for most operations that specify an image file.
segment.target: An index or name value is required for most operations that specify an image file.

segment.source: Type the following command to mount the image.
segment.target: Type the following command to mount the image.

segment.source: Type the following command to add a language pack to the mounted offline image.
segment.target: Type the following command to add a language pack to the mounted offline image.

segment.source: You can add multiple packages on one command line.
segment.target: You can add multiple packages on one command line.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The scratch directory must be at least 1 GB for adding language packs.
segment.target: The scratch directory must be at least 1 GB for adding language packs.

segment.source: Type the following command to commit the changes.
segment.target: Type the following command to commit the changes.

segment.source: The image remains mounted until the /unmount option is used.
segment.target: The image remains mounted until the /unmount option is used.

segment.source: The language packs are added to the Windows image.
segment.target: The language packs are added to the Windows image.

segment.source: The next step is to Configure International Settings.
segment.target: The next step is to Configure International Settings.

segment.source: To add a language pack using an answer file and DISM
segment.target: To add a language pack using an answer file and DISM

segment.source: Note the location of the language packs you want to add to the Windows image.
segment.target: Note the location of the language packs you want to add to the Windows image.

segment.source: Language packs are stored in .cab files and are called Lp.cab.
segment.target: Language packs are stored in .cab files and are called Lp.cab.

segment.source: Use Windows SIM to create an answer file that contains only the language packs that you want to add.
segment.target: Use Windows SIM to create an answer file that contains only the language packs that you want to add.

segment.source: For more information about how to create an answer file, see Create or Open an Answer File.
segment.target: For more information about how to create an answer file, see Create or Open an Answer File.

segment.source: In the Package node, under Language Packs, right-click the language pack that you want to add, and then select Add to Answer File.
segment.target: In the Package node, under Language Packs, right-click the language pack that you want to add, and then select Add to Answer File.

segment.source: In the Properties pane, under Settings, select the Install value for the Action setting.
segment.target: In the Properties pane, under Settings, select the Install value for the Action setting.

segment.source: You can also configure international settings in the answer file.
segment.target: You can also configure international settings in the answer file.

segment.source: For more information, see Configure International Settings in Windows.
segment.target: For more information, see Configure International Settings in Windows.

segment.source: Validate and save the answer file.
segment.target: Validate and save the answer file.

segment.source: Close Windows SIM.
segment.target: Close Windows SIM.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Make sure that the language pack is copied to the location specified in the answer file.
segment.target: Make sure that the language pack is copied to the location specified in the answer file.

segment.source: If the image is not already mounted, use DISM to mount the Windows image.
segment.target: If the image is not already mounted, use DISM to mount the Windows image.

segment.source: For example,
segment.target: For example,

segment.source: Use DISM to apply the unattended installation answer file to the mounted Windows image.
segment.target: Use DISM to apply the unattended installation answer file to the mounted Windows image.

segment.source: For example,
segment.target: For example,

segment.source: For more information about how to apply an unattended answer file by using DISM, see DISM Unattended Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about how to apply an unattended answer file by using DISM, see DISM Unattended Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: The language packs are added to the Windows image, and international settings are configured.
segment.target: The language packs are added to the Windows image, and international settings are configured.

segment.source: Remove a Language Pack from a Windows Image
segment.target: Remove a Language Pack from a Windows Image

segment.source: Before you add new language packs to a Windows image, you must remove any language packs that you do not intend to use.
segment.target: Before you add new language packs to a Windows image, you must remove any language packs that you do not intend to use.

segment.source: There are two ways to remove language packs offline with DISM.
segment.target: There are two ways to remove language packs offline with DISM.

segment.source: You can either apply an unattended answer file to the offline image, or you can remove the language pack directly from the offline image, using the command prompt.
segment.target: You can either apply an unattended answer file to the offline image, or you can remove the language pack directly from the offline image, using the command prompt.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: You cannot remove a language pack from an offline Windows image if there are pending online actions.
segment.target: You cannot remove a language pack from an offline Windows image if there are pending online actions.

segment.source: The Windows image should be a recently installed and captured image.
segment.target: The Windows image should be a recently installed and captured image.

segment.source: This will guarantee that the Windows image does not have any pending online actions that require a reboot.
segment.target: This will guarantee that the Windows image does not have any pending online actions that require a reboot.

segment.source: To remove a language pack using DISM
segment.target: To remove a language pack using DISM

segment.source: Locate the Windows image (.wim) file or virtual hard disk (.vhd or .vhdx) that contains the Windows image that you intend to remove languages from.
segment.target: Locate the Windows image (.wim) file or virtual hard disk (.vhd or .vhdx) that contains the Windows image that you intend to remove languages from.

segment.source: Click Start, and type deployment.
segment.target: Click Start, and type deployment.

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: At the command prompt, type the following command to retrieve the name or index number for the image that you want to modify.
segment.target: At the command prompt, type the following command to retrieve the name or index number for the image that you want to modify.

segment.source: An index or name value is required for most operations that specify an image file.
segment.target: An index or name value is required for most operations that specify an image file.

segment.source: Type the following command to mount the offline Windows image.
segment.target: Type the following command to mount the offline Windows image.

segment.source: Optional: Type the following command to list the languages in the offline image.
segment.target: Optional: Type the following command to list the languages in the offline image.

segment.source: Type the following command to remove a language pack from the image.
segment.target: Type the following command to remove a language pack from the image.

segment.source: You can remove multiple .cab files by using one command-line statement.
segment.target: You can remove multiple .cab files by using one command-line statement.

segment.source: Type the following command to commit the changes.
segment.target: Type the following command to commit the changes.

segment.source: The image remains mounted until the /unmount option is used.
segment.target: The image remains mounted until the /unmount option is used.

segment.source: The language packs are removed from your image.
segment.target: The language packs are removed from your image.

segment.source: The next step is to add a language pack to the mounted offline image.
segment.target: The next step is to add a language pack to the mounted offline image.

segment.source: To continue, see Add a Language Pack to a Windows Image.
segment.target: To continue, see Add a Language Pack to a Windows Image.

segment.source: To remove a language pack using DISM and an unattended answer file
segment.target: To remove a language pack using DISM and an unattended answer file

segment.source: Use Windows® System Image Manager (Windows SIM) to create an answer file that contains only the language packs that you want to remove.
segment.target: Use Windows® System Image Manager (Windows SIM) to create an answer file that contains only the language packs that you want to remove.

segment.source: Open the Windows image by using Windows SIM and create a new answer file.
segment.target: Open the Windows image by using Windows SIM and create a new answer file.

segment.source: For more information about how to use Windows SIM, see Create or Open an Answer File.
segment.target: For more information about how to use Windows SIM, see Create or Open an Answer File.

segment.source: In the Package node, under Language Packs, right-click the language pack that you want to remove and select Add to Answer File.
segment.target: In the Package node, under Language Packs, right-click the language pack that you want to remove and select Add to Answer File.

segment.source: In the Properties pane, under Settings, select the Remove value for the Action setting.
segment.target: In the Properties pane, under Settings, select the Remove value for the Action setting.

segment.source: Save the answer file and close Windows SIM.
segment.target: Save the answer file and close Windows SIM.

segment.source: The answer file must resemble the following example.
segment.target: The answer file must resemble the following example.

segment.source: Use DISM to mount the Windows image.
segment.target: Use DISM to mount the Windows image.

segment.source: For example,
segment.target: For example,

segment.source: Use DISM to apply the unattended answer file to the mounted Windows image.
segment.target: Use DISM to apply the unattended answer file to the mounted Windows image.

segment.source: For example,
segment.target: For example,

segment.source: For more information about how to use DISM to apply an unattended answer file, see DISM Unattended Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about how to use DISM to apply an unattended answer file, see DISM Unattended Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: Type the following command to commit the changes.
segment.target: Type the following command to commit the changes.

segment.source: The image remains mounted until the /unmount option is used.
segment.target: The image remains mounted until the /unmount option is used.

segment.source: The language packs are removed from your image.
segment.target: The language packs are removed from your image.

segment.source: The next step is to add a language pack to the mounted offline image.
segment.target: The next step is to add a language pack to the mounted offline image.

segment.source: To continue, see Add a Language Pack to a Windows Image.
segment.target: To continue, see Add a Language Pack to a Windows Image.

segment.source: Configure International Settings
segment.target: Configure International Settings

segment.source: After you add or remove a language pack in a Windows image, you can set the default user interface (UI) language, which is also known as the display language.
segment.target: After you add or remove a language pack in a Windows image, you can set the default user interface (UI) language, which is also known as the display language.

segment.source: At the same time, you can configure the international settings in the Windows image using DISM.
segment.target: At the same time, you can configure the international settings in the Windows image using DISM.

segment.source: You can also configure international settings in an answer file.
segment.target: You can also configure international settings in an answer file.

segment.source: For more information about how to do this, see Configure International Settings in Windows.
segment.target: For more information about how to do this, see Configure International Settings in Windows.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If you specify a default UI language and locale settings with the DISM tool, and then specify different language and locale settings in an answer file, the settings in the answer file overwrite the default values specified by the DISM tool.
segment.target: If you specify a default UI language and locale settings with the DISM tool, and then specify different language and locale settings in an answer file, the settings in the answer file overwrite the default values specified by the DISM tool.

segment.source: To configure international settings using DISM
segment.target: To configure international settings using DISM

segment.source: You must first mount the image if it is not already mounted.
segment.target: You must first mount the image if it is not already mounted.

segment.source: For example,
segment.target: For example,

segment.source: To change all international language settings in the mounted offline image to match the default values set by Microsoft for a given language, at the DISM command prompt, type the following command,
segment.target: To change all international language settings in the mounted offline image to match the default values set by Microsoft for a given language, at the DISM command prompt, type the following command,

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The /Set-SKUIntlDefaults option does not change the keyboard driver for Japanese and Korean keyboards.
segment.target: The /Set-SKUIntlDefaults option does not change the keyboard driver for Japanese and Korean keyboards.

segment.source: You must use the /Set-LayeredDriver option to change this.
segment.target: You must use the /Set-LayeredDriver option to change this.

segment.source: For more information, see DISM Languages and International Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information, see DISM Languages and International Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: For more information about default values, see Windows Language Pack Default Values.
segment.target: For more information about default values, see Windows Language Pack Default Values.

segment.source: Optionally, you can configure different values for different settings, including UI language, system locale, user locale, input locale, and others.
segment.target: Optionally, you can configure different values for different settings, including UI language, system locale, user locale, input locale, and others.

segment.source: For more information about how to specify individual values for each of these settings, see DISM Languages and International Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about how to specify individual values for each of these settings, see DISM Languages and International Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: At a command prompt, type the following command to commit the changes and unmount the image.
segment.target: At a command prompt, type the following command to commit the changes and unmount the image.

segment.source: The Windows image is ready to be deployed.
segment.target: The Windows image is ready to be deployed.
